events.title: Warm Data Lab
events.description: Nora Bateson defined the term “Warm Data” in 2012 as “contextual and relational information about complex systems. The Lab strengthens groups’ collective ability to perceive, discuss, and design responses to “wicked” problems through immersive exercises and deep conversations.

events.title: Understanding Data Rights and Tactics for Data Defense
events.description: In this workshop, participants will learn about the basics of data rights as a liberatory framework and begin identifying a opportunities for data rights to play a role in their organizing. Through a hands-on workshop activity, we’ll explore specific tactics that can help organizers understand how to fight back when data is being used as a tool to reinforce systems of oppression. Together we’ll explore how data rights can help us reclaim control over our communities’ information and cultural knowledge through data justice organizing.

events.title: Collaboratively Creating Flexible Data Science Learning Tools
events.description: In this workshop, we will share the process of working collaboratively with high school teachers to create learning materials.  This free web applet helps Minnesota students explore local air quality by locating the nearest monitoring station and examining both natural and human-made influences on their air quality. We will then encourage participants to explore the app, determine their own questions, and offer suggestions about improvements.

events.title: The Family Business: What Monster-Fighting in Bitter Root Teaches Us About Gender and Resistance
Part 1- Beyond Belonging: Cultivating Thriving Spaces in STEAM
events.description: The workshop equips participants with hands-on learning experiences that foster engaging, joyful learning environments grounded in liberatory practices that center belonging, healing-centered education, critical love, positive racial identity, agency, sociopolitical consciousness, and culturally responsive practices.

events.title: From Data Transcript to Narrative Tools: A Workshop on Using Participant-Centered Data in Transformative Ways.
Carcerality And Education
events.description:
"This workshop is a train-the-trainer workshop so that attendees can bring this curriculum back to their community.  In this session, we will share our experiences as we developed and delivered this as an education studies class in the spring of 2025.  In the class, we examined how “carcerality” is an organizing feature of public education in the U.S. by exploring disciplinary processes, technology, and surveillance practices, curricular norms, and the built environment in schools, as well as attempts to challenge such carceral logics, especially through organized efforts of communities of color. 

Goal: Introduce syllabus and opportunities to deliver classes at schools and in the community.  This session will highlight, readings, activities, project work and resources to successfully deliver this curriculum. "

events.title: FASTER, SMARTER, LONELIER: Reclaiming Humanity in the Age of AI
events.description:
"As technology accelerates, many of us are quietly losing the most irreplaceable part of our lives: our presence. In this intimate, story driven session, we will explore how the pursuit of convenience and automation is quietly disconnecting us from each other, and how reclaiming small moments of presence can be a radical act of justice, care, and community building.

Through personal storytelling, audience reflection, and real world examples from Denmark’s slow checkout lanes to AI supported classrooms, this session invites us to imagine a world where technology serves humanity, not replaces it. We will examine who gets erased first when people are removed from design, why connection must be the foundation of any just future, and how AI, when used intentionally, can return time to our lives rather than steal it.

Participants will leave not with a to do list, but with a question:

What small, beautiful moment will you choose to protect?

This session is for anyone who cares about digital justice, ethical technology, and the quiet power of being human together."

events.title: Conversation & Performance
events.description: Vyjayanthi Vadrevu in conversation with Aasim Shabazz

events.title: "Access as Surveillance: Edtech and Perpetually At-Risk Youth"
events.description: Based on examples from the book Access Is Capture: How Edtech Reproduces Racial Inequality, this presentation will focus on data-intensive education technology (edtech) and how its use contributes to surveillance abuse. While the evidence of the value of edtech to contemporary learning is exaggerated, many very real harms related to surveillance abuse have been underreported. Based on the work of community organizers active in anti-surveillance and youth movements, I propose a few questions schools, parents, and education professionals of all kinds might ask before incorporating edtech into classroom learning.
